_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This is to inform all interested persons, including employees, that the Ohio Valley Division- Supervalu Holding Inc.'s Xenia Ohio Distribution Center is in compliance with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29.Code of Federal Regulations (CFR) 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP), Title CFR Part 68 to deal with the risks involved with the storage or use of hazardous chemicals.

The Ohio Valley Distribution Center is a wholesale food distribution facility, having two ammonia compressor rooms. One system consisting of 14,800 lbs. Controls temperatures in the freezer. The second system is a 6,000 lb. Capacity system controlling the temperature in the Perishable building.

The freezer has frozen product, i.e.: meat, ice cream, vegetables, breads, cakes, pre-packaged meals and anything else that can typically be found in the frozen department of any grocery store. The Perishable building products are those items that need temperature control but should not be frozen. These items might be packaged meats, dairy products and poultry.

PSM and RMP. As well as many safety policies within our facility, enable us to prevent the occurance, minimize the consequenses of significant releases of ammonia, as well as fires, explosions and other types of catastrophic accidents. Additionally, these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries and ilnesses, and avoid physical property damage.

Anhydrous Ammonia is the only hazardous chemical that is over the threshold quantity. Other hazardous materials are in-house, but in quantities below their threshold levels. Regardless, accepted industry safety practices, such as MSDS sheets, proper storage, personal protective equipment, etc., are used religiously. These products are typical of what one would find in a maintenance shop servicing a building or related fork truck type equipment.

The ammonia refrigeration system consists of compressors, vessels, condensers, evaporators,piping and pumps, and are i

nterconnected into one system.

We believe our safety programs prevent accidents due to our focus on rules, procedures, and practices which govern individual processes, work performed, or pieces of equipment. These rules are detailed and updated as necessary. Employees are included in the "Management of Change" or rules changes.
